description:
Great Food,
Fast service 
The best Chinese food I ate lately.
Cash only, no CC accepted.
author: Dimitre I.

description:
So, I went here with my friend and we decided to start off with some egg rolls. The egg rolls were fried very nicely. When we started to eat them, we found a few pieces of cabbage, and that was about it. It just seemed like a really lazy tourist trap of a restaurant. 

However, they had a lot of options on their menu so I really don't want to slam them for one bad dish. So if you go here, maybe just get something different than the egg rolls.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
A San Francisco China Town delight if you are in the mood, it is cash only, English speaking friendly and good food.  Every seat in this little restaurant was full and the place was busy.  

I tend to prefer sticky rice but they put on a fried rice that was light and pleasantly surprising as it was served with their combo for 2.  Service was done with a smile and they were very attentive.

The sweet and sour pork is usually my go to and it met my expectations, though, the cashew chicken surprised me and almost stole the show.
author: Jay P.

description:
So as tourist in a new town, we have no idea where to go.  I thought this might be a decent place, even though the outside appearance doesn't look that great with a busted door.

We ordered a the lunch special.  The g/f had some sort of noodles with beef, can't recall the exact name.  I ordered a curry chicken with white rice.  It's east asian style curry chicken so it's more watered down.  I liked my curry chicken.  I asked for mild, and it delivers.  The chicken itself was very fresh.  I chow that down within a couple minutes.  Meanwhile, the g/f did not like her noodles with beef at all.  She said it was tasteless, it lack sauce, and looks nothing like the photo.  

The server was an older gentleman.  He was pleasant with us, maybe because I'm able to speak Chinese??  It was an okay place for cheap lunch.
author: Jake L.

description:
I've eaten at many places in China Town and this one is my favorite! The food is flavorful and fresh. To me, Chinese food is good when there is no need to add soy sauce to the dish! 

I have been here more than once and the food is great every time! I've had the pot stickers, chicken chow mein, beef chow fun, orange chicken, broccoli beef, and sesame chicken! All super good! 

The dress code is casual and the prices are low. 

And they give you free tea and sell beer and wine! 

This place is a hidden gem and a must try for any Chinese food lover!
author: Michelle Z.

description: My wife and I shared the orange chicken with white rice and the chicken was delicious. Right amount of flour batter, seasoning and cooking time. It tasted fresh and fried just right. The orange sauce tasted great with a good sweet and sour balanced flavor. We did not care much for the white rice, but the chicken....
author: David O.

description:
So my wife had tried this place not too long ago and wanted me to give it a try too. It wasn't what she experienced the first time.  

Interestingly, this place opens at 11:30 instead of 11 am like any other restaurant, but that's understandable. Everything started off good, the server (who wasn't too friendly but that's alright) brought us hot tea and took our order pretty promptly. We had just ordered lunch specials, sweet&sour chicken and peking baby ribs, but then decided to get fried shrimp after we placed our oder and the server was able to bring our appetizer before our lunch which I was very pleased. The shrimp and s&s chicken were pretty good but the baby ribs tasted like they've been refrigerated for a while or something. 

The real reason why I gave this place a 2 star is because of the service, not only was our server a little rude but when he brought us our bill we see a grand total of $37 for 2 lunch specials $8.95 ea and a shrimp appetizer with 9 shrimps for $12.95.  Upon checking the tab, I see an interesting SV charge of $4.60 and when we asked the server, he said it was a service charge.  Now, I've worked in the restaurant industry for 7 years and my wife for 4 and we've never seen a "service" charge, maybe gratuity on 6 or more people but certainly not on a 2 top. He didn't explain much about the charge when he took the money from my wife's hand and walked away to cash us out without letting us talk. We were both very mad he did that!  
If he would've been friendlier and not enforce his "SV charge" maybe we would've given this place another try. But after how he treated us, we're definitely not going back.  I'm all for tipping your server, after all, thats what they live off of, but theres a difference between deserving a tip and demanding it. It's sad that even if you have a good product but your customer service is lacking, you can really hurt your business and create a bad reputation.
author: Miguel P.

description: Found bugs in my food. And there were alot of bugs in soy sauce jars. The man didn't even offer accommodation. Don't ever go here! Enough said!!
author: Julie K.

description: I ventured in here while in China town. Friend and I were enticed by the "dinner for 2" deals they had. The server was an older fellow and brought us hot tea. Don't use their bathroom, it's dirty. My friend needed to charge her phone, and the man let her use one of his side outlets. When we were ready to order we tried ordering the "dinner for 2" at a rate of $16.95, but upon ordering we were informed it was $16.95 per person. I thought, "what? Why would you advertise dinner for 2, if you're posting the price of one meal?", it just doesn't make sense to me. So we ended up ordering a different deal for $12.95 which included hot and sour soup, which I may add was so delicious, an egg roll, sweet and sour pork and pork fried rice. The egg roll was good, sweet and sour pork had a nice crunch to it but I found a couple chewy pieces I didn't care for, and the pork fried rice was good but the egg pieces were quite large, made me feel like I had a side of scrambled egg with my rice, and it also included sautéed lettuce... lettuce! The lettuce wasn't bad, it was different, but halfway into it I found myself scooping away the lettuce and the big chunks of egg. I'm not a picky eater by any means, but this just wasn't my lucky day. Over I rate it an ok lunch with my friend, I liked how the man let my friend charge her phone and he brought us tea, but get this... as I went up to pay, the man gave me my change and told me the tip wasn't included. I asked what he meant, and he clarified that he had not charged me for the tip. At that point I felt awkward, realized why he had given me back a lot of small bills for change, and told him I'd leave him one at the table on my way out. I left him $3 he quite frankly didn't deserve, but I didn't want to feel attacked on my way out. In shorter words, Food is meh... and the service wasn't bad... but bad.
author: Karina S.

description: Read the reviews for this place and thought it would be a good place to try.   Needless to say we were mislead.  Being in Chinatown we were expecting an authentic Chinese dinner.  What we received was anything but.  The food was at best cooked at a different time and reheated.  We ordered S&S Chicken, Chicken and Vegetables along with a bowl of WonTon soup.  When the food arrived we noticed that the portion size was VERY small for the price of the plate.  Even the fortune cookies were stale.  Unfortunately I cannot in good conscience recommend this establishment.
author: Patrick D.

description: Quite possibly the worst Chinese food I've ever had.  The beef tasted like horse meat and the chicken tasted like plastic. Skip this one
author: Cody B.

description: We walked in off the street for lunch and loved it! We both got a lunch special. I got the mongolian beef over rice and the Bf got the chicken chow mein. Such a nice place. Nice service and good food. I would come back! Thank you!
author: Elana And Tamar B.

description:
Less than mediocre food. We had spareribs on rice and chicken on rice noodles. Spareribs were tough and gummy. Chicken and noodles dry (noodles were slightly burned) with no seasoning. Bland bland bland. Even the tea tasted cheap. Service was slow because there was only one waiter who was a bit surly (we didn't blame him; he was doing his best to keep up with a full restaurant). 

On top of all that, it was dirty. The restroom was pretty disgusting. There are so many good Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. Go down any street off of Grant and you'll find one. We got a bum steer on this expensive (for what we got) poor place.
author: Trish H.

description: I mean, I got some pretty great fried rice here! Served in a HUGE to go box. Plenty to split!
author: Maxwell M.

description: The best beef and broccoli we ever had. The beef was so tender and sauce very tasty. Nice stop during our Chinatown visit.
author: Linda W.

description:
Another reviewer said this is what happens when you're hungry and desperate and that sums it up perfectly.  

The Scene:
American Chinese food and kitsch "classic" decor.  The cook has a radio blasting in Chinese in the kitchen.  The whole place feels dated and tired.  The walls are covered in mirrored panels to make this narrow space seem larger.  Our waiter was an older man who was polite but also seemed sleepy.  I didn't venture into the restroom so I can't comment on that.  

The Meal:
We tried the General's Chicken and a mixed-seafood/veggie dish, steamed white rice, and BBQ pork fried rice.  Nothing tasted fresh.  Nothing was above room temperature.  Everything was below average even for an "Americanized" Chinese food standard.  Mixed seafood/veggie had mostly rubbery, dry, flavorless squid, more peas than any other veg, and watery "sauce".  The General's Chicken dish was much too sweet, chicken was dry and over breaded, too salty and just not good.  

The Price/Payment:
Prices are too high for the serving size and the low quality of the food.  As others have mentioned, it was disturbing that the waiter took our credit card and walked out front.  We assume they process cards at a nearby shop but we'll be keeping an eye on our Visa statement in case of "unauthorized activity".  

Very disappointing experience since we know that San Francisco is a foodie town, and there surely must be good, authentic Chinese food elsewhere.  

Would not recommend or return to Snow Garden.
author: Tina P.

description:
Came back to this place after enjoying my visit three years ago. I was disappointed this time. I remembered the vegetable fried rice as the best I'd ever had. It wasn't. 

Tea is served to everyone, which I appreciated. I ordered the vegetarian combination. Although everything looked good, it didn't taste good. I thought my food overly greasy, and didn't stand out in any way. The vegetables seemed canned or frozen. Lunch for two amounted to $30, and it just doesn't seem worth it. I would not go back.
author: Ashton N.

description:
Quick service. Lousy food. 

If you're expecting authentic Chinese look elsewhere. A greasy plate of bland rice noodles and chicken is what I attempted to eat. Wife ate vegetable dish. Veggies looked like they were frozen or canned.

The wife insisted on revisiting this place as she has been here before. I may be picky but I could tell by the generic menu and dirty shabby establishment it was a loss. Oh well gotta keep her happy! 

Walked out paying over $30 for lunch and 1 beer. Won't visit again.
author: John N.

description:
Perfect example of a whole in the wall! Just walking around exploring China Town and was craving soup but many places were closed. 

The server was very polite and attentive. I ordered the shrimp ball wonton soup. It was delicious and hit the spot!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Went here for lunch yesterday with two adults and four kids. 

Service was incredibly slow and unpredictable. But worse, the food was horrible. Talk about a gut bomb. My stomach still hurts the next day!

The fried wontons were soggy, there was more bean sprouts than noddles in the chow mien. The beef in the broccoli beef was thin, chewy and sparse. The fried rice was very wet. It was all just not good. 

Our kids left hungry and unsatisfied which sucks because my kids love Chinese food. 

On top of the slow service and bad food, the bill was super high. So overpriced, bad food. Blah. 

Oh well. On to a different China Town restaurant.
author: Alexis M.

description:
Super slow service
I made a complain after 30 min. Waiting for my food, the owner smiled at me and said i have only one staff in the kitchen.
I don't want to hear that as a customer. The fact that he smiles and think now that he has only one staff in his filthy kitchen, his slow service is excuse, is unbelievable.
author: Tattooed I.

description: We were in area and I looked up reviews and popped in for some orange chicken and sweet n sour chicken. Rice n egg rolls too. Everything was great. Small modest place. Just the type I Iike - very clean pretty simple menu but the real deal. Even the hot black tea-- couldn't get enough!! Hope they don't change a thing!!
author: Rich M.

description: Was feeling down with cold and got a Chicken Soup from here. The broth was Ok but there was barely any chicken in it. I asked to makes it spicy and they added chili flakes. It still wasn't spicy, but Sriracha will do the trick. $12 was a bit steep for a simple Chicken soup with next to no chicken in it
author: Nishant A.

description:
Literately the best Chinese food I've ever had. The waiter is this sweet older Chinese man. I had the orange chicken and steamed rice and my fiancé had the chicken dumplings which he loved 

warning  - once you eat here no other Chinese food place will taste the same
author: Ana C.

description: Delicious, well-priced, friendly staff, and quick service. Really neat location. Happy we visited.
author: Bri S.

description:
We went in off the street for some tea; ended up getting egg rolls and moo shu pork, too.  The egg rolls were fresh and delicious and the moo shu pork was really, really good!  We really liked the little guy who does the waiting - very friendly and helpful, and quite accommodating.  

We returned later that week for lunch again and had two very nice dishes.  Wife had hot/sour soup which she enjoyed very much and sweet/sour pork that was good, but not great.  My Mongolian beef was very good - nice portion and very tasty - just about right spice-wise.

Overall two good experiences -
author: Danny W.

description: Update - I got food poisoning after eating this so I guess that confirmed my suspicions about this place.
author: Gina C.

description:
Great food, great atmosphere, quick and easy to order!
The lemon chicken stuff, was AMAZING! And unlike other places it was sweet, which was a pleasant surprise!
It is easy to order and for you to understand them, which is nice in china town.
author: Justin W.

description: Had high expectations from a Chinese restaurant in China Town.  Very disappointed.  Got the beef and broccoli and cashew chicken.  Both were very salty and the meet was fatty.
author: Art M.

description:
Food was delicious! But idk how I ended up paying $17 for a plate of food and a small wonton soup :/

Anywho, I'd come back but with CASH. The poor guy had to go next door to ring me up for my order.
author: JG I.

description: Just bring cash, ask cost? great food and service
author: Angelina M.

description:
Walnut Shrimp...Delicious.  Shrimp Fried Rice...Delicious.
Bathroom...Pretty Clean.

This is what I picture the typical Chinatown restaurant to look like.  Reasonably inexpensive, not super clean or super dirty.. and nice big pictures of Chinese things all over the restaurant.  The place was not too crowded either.  In case you're not sure where it is, just walk past the lady yelling about $3.95 dim sum (which is way too expensive for dim sum however, it is all day dim sum) and its right next door.  

By far my favorite Chinese restaurant.  Will return and hopefully try everything on the menu.  

The Walnut Shrimp was very good, not too much mayo which is a pet peeve of mine.  And, the walnuts were not too sweet either.  I eaten a lot of Walnut Shrimps at a dozen or so fancy Chinese Restaurants and Snow Garden had the best I've ever had...so far.
author: Hazel K.

description:
My fiancé and I did not enjoy the food at all. The chicken and salted fish fried rice was undercooked and by salted they mean fermented.  The ingredients in their beef noodle soup did not seem fresh. It's a little pricey for the quality of food you get. The only bright side was the friendly waiter, he was quick and attentive. 

If you are looking for a meal in Chinatown, don't go here. The prices, ingredient quality, and tea are all wrong. 

They earned a two instead of a one because of their service, whom were very attentive, not their food, which I thought was poor.
author: Andrew C.

description: Shitty aff my cousins and i were desperate so we decided to give this place a try. The food is your typical americanized chinese food however it has no flavor whatsoever and its suuper over priced!! This dude charged our one app 3 times because it was 3 of us like cool dude? I ended up with a huge stomach ache and a need to throw up! Just do yourself a favor and eat somewhere else
author: Giselle H.

description:
Food is not fresh, my mongolian beef was every color of the rainbow, I know its not poisonous to eat beef that is that color, but how unappetizing..

As for the dish itself, very bland and just did not taste like a proper meal prepared by a chef. I could do better in my kitchen with a mongolian beef sauce packet and some ingredients.

I also love how they have a "people love us on Yelp" sticker posted on their window. 3 stars overall and their first page is littered with 1 star reviews, I sure hope they feel that love and make some changes. I hate restaurants that only care about making money and forget about the passion and love for delicious food that should be the driving force behind any chef and his/her restaurant. Two thumbs down for this place
author: Danny L.

description:
This place was not good. I guess my friend & I decided on the wrong Chinese restaurant tonight. We were the only customers there and I didn't realize they were closing soon. Had they let us know they were gonna close soon we would've have gone somewhere else, no problem. Of course, money is money. We ordered the chicken in black bean sauce and chicken chow mein. Our meal was prepared quickly and the chicken was so undercooked. All white and tasteless. We both love black bean sauce and I guess they couldn't bother to make that taste good. Then they were watching to see when I'd pay the bill. They just really wanted us out and so undercooked our meal. To top it all off, it was cash only. They need to have a bigger sign on the window that says "cash only". Better communication would help this place, I don't like being that last customer cos I know how irritating is, I wouldn't have mind if they told us "we're closing soon." 

TL ; DR? : Poor customer service and not so good food.
author: Stars S.

description:
Try the Orange Peel Chicken, its delicious (comparable to Orange Chicken). 
Restaurant should consider getting a fountain drink machine rather charging $2 per Coke. That's right, no free refills.
author: Jay B.

description: We ordered shrimp fried rice, scallops with veggies, Mongolian beef, and cashew chicken. There wasn't anything left when we finished eating. It was very good!
author: Brian W.

description: Hidden gem. I walked in randomly and the food was so authentic that I feel like I'm in China! Service is great too.
author: Yizhou H.

description: Excellent food in a very small unpretentious restaurant. The BBQ pork won ton soup is packed full of delicious won tons, BBQ roasted pork, and bok choy. Also had the ribs (amazing riblets) and beef chow fun with peppers and black beans. Delicious. The service was very good too. I will be going back here next time I am in the city.
author: Alisa B.

description:
Nice find on Grant Street. Love the Beef & Broccoli! Pot stickers, egg rolls, shrimp fried rice & honey lemon chicken were dynamite!!!
Prompt service!
author: Robert M.

description: Was so hungry in Chinatown and went into Snow Garden. I had three entrees with fried rice and it is so nice. I can taste home and it is authentic Chinese food for sure. The restaurant was kind of small but the staff is friendly.
author: Joie H.

description: The food portions are fairly large which is nice because each dish is about $10 or more! The experience is a little awkward... they seat you and then take forever to take your order. Then they forgot one of our sodas and we kept having to remind them to bring it to us. Anyways, it's worth a try but after spending over 50 bucks for 3 people I probably won't be back.
author: Justine C.

description: This place gets a 5 star because of how damn good the food is, the decor is mediocre, service is decent, but oh my days, this food is unbelievable, order the chicken fried rice and sesame chicken and share them both with someone, you will not be disappointed
author: Omar S.

description:
Snow Garden is my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  I discovered it by accident on my first trip here as we were just wandering around and got hungry.  We went in because it looked cheap, but ended up having one of the best meals of the trip, and now a visit to Snow Garden is on the to-do list for every San Francisco visit.  

Unlike most of the restaurants in Chinatown, Snow Garden's business model isn't to draw in tourists with a "look how Chinese we are" vibe.  There aren't any ostentatious decorations.  It's not ugly and there are a couple nice paintings inside, but it's a place you go for food, not for ambiance.  And the food will not disappoint you.  

There's almost no point recommending any particular dishes, because you can just pick something at random and it will be great.  But I will say that their chow mein is probably the best noodles I've had outside China itself, and their special sets are a great deal.  

If you are looking for a touristy place that you can take pictures of, somewhere that looks typically Chinatown, this is not the place for you.  If you are looking for great food, this is the best spot in Chinatown.
author: Michael F.

description: Went here when my in-laws were visiting. Good service, great food. I had the sesame chicken with rice, and it was delicious!
author: Alex L.

description:
Small place with tile floor, a walk-in tourist clientele and old dilapidated decor.  I had a craving for greasy authentic Chinatown Chinese but this place wasn't great.  

Hot&Sour Soup:  Too sour with pickles or something and I found peas in a few spoonfuls.  Overpriced at $9.  Peas don't belong in Hot&Sour soup!  Consistency was a bit watery and there was no solid meat items.

Shrimp Dumplings:  exterior was good but shrimp was a bit fishy and had a Chlorine odor.

Roast Duck:  this was actually pretty good and a good deal at $7.50 but not as delicious as a properly cooked Peking duck- it was a bit too oily.

Management is very nice though and I feel bad for them that their restaurant isn't better.
author: M S.

description: I discovered this place exploring china town in San Francisco I was looking around for some good egg rolls and I came apon this place  out of a few that I seen, I ordered 2 orders of egg rolls which you get 3 pieces each order.  Amazingly delicious and very crispy close to a spring roll and the sauce they give you with your order is sooooo good, next time I'm in San Fran china town I will stop in and eat here.
author: Edwin R.

description: The appetizers and soup were pretty good but the main course was horrible. The beef was an off color or and very chewy. The chicken was rock hard and was hard to eat.
author: Joshua W.

description:
BALLOON BELLIE!!!!
(3.5 stars)

It had a "Yelp Loves Us" sticker at the window which made me stop and check it out. I'm not a tourist but tourists were in there and all i heard were "so delicious" coming from a tourist mouth; that can be skeptical. The sign should read "Non-Asian/Tourist Love Us".

- Food, meh - not bad, aiight i guess
- Prices, inexpensive 
- Portions, bellybomb
- Ambiance, hole-in-butt-crack-nowhere

Decided to take a walk during lunch break and catch some vitamin D in this 90-degree weather. Not sure how or why I found myself in Chinatown. And eating greasy chinese food -- i'm rebelling against my diet today. And why do the staff look sad when they welcome you, take your order, server you, and give you the bill? I thought yelp loves you?!

Ordered, paid with my card, server takes my card OUT THE BUILDING and comes back a few minutes with a receipt. I'm confused.... and scared.... at the same time. I see the drink was $2, why didnt anyone tell me in advance a can soda was going to cost 125% more than it should cost. 

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

Cashew Chicken over Rice (7.95) - Good chicken pieces, tender, white meat, cashews were good, and fresh vegtable used. I actually wish they had more vegtables, others may disagree. This dish is really a five dollar kind of dish but its right on Grant where all tourists are walking so i can see the prices hiked. if people think thats cheap for this dish, you really have no idea. I'll call this cheap for the portions they served. My portion could feed at least 3 people. Is my belly full of MSG? I asked no MSG but after 5 bites i was feeling the heaviness. My belly looks like a damn balloon after eating 1/3 of my food. 

7-UP ($2) - Who the hell pays $2 for a can soda? Seriously, that's ridiculous. It was either that or nasty chinatown tap water. 

Will I be back? There are may other hole-in-butt-crack-nowhere restaurants to get decent Chinese food. this is one of them but I can re-route myself to another place.


I don't know how yelp loves you, I dont, i just think "you will do"

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: One of the worst restaurants I've been to. Super salty mixed seafood and nasty Mongolian beef. That's what happens when you hungry and desperate.
author: Anh N.

description:
Chinatown is set up to attract tourists and their money.  Its tenants see out-of-towners coming a mile away, and are more than happy to cater to their expectations of what a Chinatown should be.  Impressive gate, check; illegible signs piled on top of each other, check; overpriced, mediocre restaurants that have only the appearance of authenticity, check.  The Chinatown in your mind is beckoning to you from Grant Avenue, and is ripe for the taking -- for the right price.

Don't buy into it.

Reject the Chinatown of five postcards for a dollar, fresh-from-the-sweatshop undersized T-shirts, and flimsy paper folding fans. 

Pass up the self-righteous tourist trap restaurants, with their ostentatious dragon-wrapped faux jade columns, vermillion pagoda rooflines, and surly dim sum ladies.  These places talk a big game, but underdeliver on both food and service.

Whatever you do, don't even set foot in Empress of China.  You're not famous enough to end up on their wall anyway.

If you go to Chinatown, make it a different kind of Chinatown -- the Chinatown of Snow Garden.

Snow Garden sees you coming too, but they know you are coming in because you are hungry, not just because you want to "eat in Chinatown".  They are unassuming enough to be passed up by most tourists, who still have that image in their head of what they think Chinatown is.

They will sell you a comfortable-sized combo for one for 12 bucks, serve it to you in 5 minutes, and won't charge you extra for tea.

They know you won't care if the server reads the paper while you are eating, or that they take deliveries through the front.

But most importantly of all, the place is clean, the food is delicious, and those two things alone will keep you coming back for more.

Snow Garden is my Chinatown -- and it can be yours, too, if you challenge your expectations.
author: Erik A.

description: Place is small food came out really fast. Chicken salad was horrible but the lemon chicken was really good. Wasn't a fan of the hot & sour soup. Their 2 people deal is a good price.
author: Yvette M.

description: Excellent food!!! Great service!! Great prices!!! Feed 9 people under $110 including tip
author: Brian K.

description: This is a great restaurant if your looking for some authentic Chinese food.The chow mein is delicious. My friend and I were greeted immediately as we walked in and seated shortly, then served fresh tea. The only reason I do not give this place a 5-star is due to cleanliness (bathrooms)..but otherwise it is a delightful place to dine!
author: J S.

description:
Visiting San Francisco for the first time. Was in the mood for Chinese so I stop by here.  The waiter was very reserved and antisocial which already created a bad environment.. 
I ordered chow mein which came about 10 minutes after ordering.
It was bitter. The chicken didn't have much flavor and when The noodles weren't as delicious either..
I prefer the good old Thai restaurant back in Orange County.
author: Cristian V.

description: We went in for lunch while walking around China town. Looked on yelp and saw it had good reviews. THEY LIED! For an appetizer we had fried dumplings. Not bad but the sauce was tangy and spicy. My wife ordered the beef with bean curd over rice. The beef tarred spoiled the bean curd was fine sauce was bland. I had the generals chicken. It was sweet and sour chicken rolled in a general sauce and was neither sweet nor spicy. We sent both dishes back and continued walking to find somewhere to eat.
author: Chris S.

description: I would def come back. The food was above average. Just some classic Chinese food! Nothing fancy.
author: Danny C.

description: Good food, good service! Had chicken chow mein, fried rice, others ate sesame chicken and chicken w black bean sauce. All great meals. Egg rolls (veggie) were so-so. I'd come back again, and recommend to others.
author: Brian M.

description: Yuk. Service was horrible. It took forever to even place our order. Staff didn't seem to care that anyone was there. Food was bland. Wouldn't eat here again. They had to go next door to run my credit card, which made me uncomfortable.
author: Lobaloba R.

description:
Talk about a hole in the wall... but then again, practically every merchant 's store in S.F. Chinatown seems like a hole - well, except for that big ass Cathay restaurant...

Shrimp fried rice - check!
Beef with tender greens - check!
Orange peel chicken - check!
Beef chow fun - check!

Everything was really delicious and fairly priced. Not much of an ambiance here, so don't expect it. It's a small joint with tables and chairs and a place for you to get your grub on - not sit over wine and chat. Service was slow but there was only one server and all tables were occupied - he was running around so at least he was trying. Although there are SO MANY Chinese restaurants to choose from in S.F., it's good to know that Snow Garden is one of them and I wouldn't hesitate to come back at all.
author: Julie B.

description: It's a very tiny place about 30 people. The foods is very good. We order special fried rice, cao pao chicken, sweet sour chicken and walnut shrimps. The price is reasonable. The customer is very nice. I would recommend it to someone. The place is located in China town so it difficult to find parking. We went there on Labor Day around 6ish so we got lucky with parking.
author: Sokha P.

description:
One of my must stop at restaurants on chinatown, its a little hole in the wall place with only one server, but its reasonably clean and the food is really good.  they've got to go next door to run your credit card so thats different.  I like this place a lot better than some of the bigger restaurants that are out handing out  menus.  Low key and simple.  Not a lot of seating and there always seems to be people in here but there always seems to be space too.

My wife is very picky about chinese food and her favorites dishes are mine as well, and that is the chicken fried rice and the noodles with chicken soup.  The soup has a fantasticly tasty broth and lots of chicken along with fat noodles and veggies in a almost too big bowl.  The chicken fired rice is super tasty with plenty of chicken and a portion size big enough for us to eat half and save the other half for another meal.

Inexpensive and good food, good combination for a place like this.
author: Chris K.

description: The food served here is definitely not authentic.  They use too much salt and way too much sugar!  On the up side our waiter was good, but not good enough to make me go back.
author: Austin S.

description: Reminds me of being back home in Hawaii.  Dishes are very tasty, servings are generous, and service was very friendly.  Salt and pepper pork chops, must have.
author: Mike C.

description: I'm giving this place 4 star because the owner is super nice, he is a one man team, he serves, he cooks and he busts the table. We had the roasted duck noodles soup which is not bad and also the beef and tomato with rice that is super yummy, and what makes it more yuuuummmy is the tenderness of the beef. Once I passed by Chinatown again, I would definitely come back here. =)
author: Sherry C.

description:
For those searching for fine dining, this isn't it!  It's a hole in the wall.  However, the great-smelling food wafting out the front door reeled us in.

Honey walnut prawns at $12.95 was a little pricey and the flavor was average, but I didn't complain because I was starving after a long day.

Spicy & Salt Pork Chops at $8.95 was actually pretty good.  Nothing to vent over.
author: Cathaleya C.

description: I expected better from a hole-in-the-wall on Chinatown's busy Grant Ave. My partner ordered Singapore noodles and I ordered shredded pork w/preserved cabbage.   The food was flavorless and disappointing.  The staff was efficient and friendly, but food was subpar.
author: Rice B.

description: We ate here last weekend when we wer in San Francisco.  I read the Yelp reviews prior to eating here.  The food was great and we received good service.  I loved the hot tea that they served as soon as you are seated.  Food was delicious and warm.  Tsing Tao beer was also a great compliment to the food as well.  I would eat here again.
author: Marianne R.

description: Price for food not worth the serving size. Food was greas and not much flavor. My pearl tea was warm with no flavor. Service was eh. Would not recommend this place.
author: Nina Lynn G.

description: My husband and I wanted good, authentic Chinese food on our evening trip to Chinatown. We settled on Snow Garden after reading Yelp reviews and were not disappointed! We ordered a combo dinner for two -- wonton soup, spring rolls, fried rice, cashew chicken and sweet/sour pork. Everything was sooo tasty. Best Chinese food ever. Definitely worth five stars. SG is a tiny place with no frills or glam and one unisex bathroom but, that being said, it's well worth the stop.
author: Melinda W.

description:
Definitely more like 3.5 stars.

My husband and I were wandering through Chinatown and and got hungry. So I grabbed my iphone and used the Yelp monocle to find a place. Turned out we were standing right in front of Snow Garden. It had an average rating of 3.5 stars so why not?

We were greeted right away with warm tea (not super hot, which was odd - to me, anyway). We ordered two plates - the Sichuan chicken and pork fried rice. The chicken was ok, met my standards since it wasn't fatty, but the fried rice was the star! This was definitely not your typical heavy fried rice. We gobbled it up since it tasted like it was made right there just for us and not just sitting in some heating pan. It didn't sink in the bottom of our stomachs like so many other fried rices and for that I am anxious to return and try more dishes.
author: Jennifer F.

description: The food was very good, but there was some confusion about the house fried rice. It was on the lunch specials menu, and the picture on the menu under the thick plastic sheet on the table looked like standard fried rice that included shrimp. I asked the waiter (which there was only 1 waiter for the entire restaurant, an old man running around like mad and even going next door to run credit cards, poor guy) if it was shrimp fried rice and he said yes. So we got it for our 6 year old. What we got was white rice with sauce, 2 small pieces of chicken, 1 shrimp, 3 pieces of chinese broccoli, and a few other random seafood items my 6 year old wouldn't eat. I would have ordered something else, but I felt like I was led to believe that this was the most basic fried rice, as shown in the picture. But that's fine...just a misunderstanding. It was very good, and I actually ended up eating his and he are most of mine, the Singapore noodles. Those were very good. I wanted them spicy, but they were mild, but that worked out since my son ended up eating that instead. My husband got the beef and peppers chow fun, and it was delicious. He also had a cup of wonton soup that was very good. Unfortunately they were unable to make the bubble tea that day, though. Not sure why.
author: Steph D.

description:
**Review only for the potstickers cuz that's all I had**

Scrumptious!
Outstanding!
Ooh-la-la!
Dy-no-mite!

I've had me plenty of potstickers in my life but these were the biggest and the best! The dipping sauce was perfect too!
author: Erika A.

description:
ooooh, Chinese food the real kind, not like Panda Express. 
The Orange Chicken was sweet (but not overpowering so) and yum. 
Shrimp fried rice was so good the family had to order another plate. 
Hot and sour soup was an unappetizing dish for me, but my family loved it. We also ordered plain Wonton soup (my favorite soups of all time) and I was not impressed.
Mongolian beef was wet with sauce and tender. Thinking about it makes me drool.
The family was satisfied and full for the next four hours (and not too much money was spent from our wallets either)! With four men in our group, I believe that that is truly an accomplishment...

I guess the bathroom had been neglected for some time because when I went in, it was like, um, ew. But customers shouldn't lose all respect for an eatery such as Snow Garden just because of a not-so-clean bathroom, so I did my business and eventually got over it. (I'm proud of myself!!)

The staff here is seriously lacking: one server/waiter, cleaning woman, and chef.
However, the food here was still goooooood, and yeah, I'll come here again when I'm craving for some authentic Chinese. (=
author: KAN N.

description: In the mood for Chinese food... Where better to go than Chinatown in downtown San Fran. This is my opinion of the following service 3/5, our server was a little overwhelmed with the lunch crowd but managed the one man show pretty ok. Cleanliness 2/5, a little soap & water will go a long way. Ambiance 3/5 definitely had the homey type feeling, but it was like being at my dirty aunts house that knows how to cook. Food presentation 3/5 simple as can be & straight to the point. Taste 4.5/5 this where I overlooked all the negatives and so-so's. To summarize this is a great place for take out, other than that u will have to be ok with being in a dive.
author: Robert V.

description: I was on a trip to San Francisco with my family, anyways we ended up in Chinatown. My wife really wanted authentic Chinese food, so we thought we'd check Snow Garden out. WOW the food was so good!!!! We ordered Mongolian Beef, Sesame Chicken, Honey Walnut Prawns, and rice all around. All the dishes arrived hot and in no time at all, and after a while, I thought "Hey since we're here, let's order some Chicken Chow Mein" the waiter said "No problem" and it arrived lightening fast. I felt so bad for the waiter, because he was the only one working! People kept coming in, but he handled it with grace and ease. Next time we're in the City and craving great Chinese food, we will know exactly were to go!
author: Stephen A.

description:
Nice little restaurant/ take out place on touristy Grant Ave, between Clay and Sac, with the regular touters next door trying to entice you into $2 dim sum or whatever the crap they have. 

The lunch specials are very good. I had the awesomly named Singapore Style Chow Rice Noodle for $7 last week, and give it a huge five stars. Lots and lots of thin rice noodles, with seafood and pork, but a little too many vegetables.

Today I had the Curry Chicken Over Rice for $6. The curry was a nice creamy Chinese curry and after mixing it into the rice it was good, but not as good as the SSCRN above. Way too many onions and green peppers for my liking.

If your in the area, and want cheep and cheerful Chinese for lunch, this place aint going to set the world on fire, but it beats a lot of places in Chinatown.
author: Joseph T.

description:
I just moved to San Francisco from New York City and in the spirit of Chinese New Year, I decided to get lunch in Chinatown. This one was rated very well so I went ahead and four myself very disappointed.

Perhaps it was because we were getting a 3:00 lunch or perhaps it was because it was Chinese new year, but this place needed more help. There was only one serve and only one guy working inthe litchan whichade the wait for our food painfully long. Once the food finally arrived, the sweet and sour prawns were delicous, but that's hard to do wrong. On the other hand, the mapo tofu was nothing like what mapo tofu should be.
author: Tian X.

description: Unremarkable. Food was fine, but no better than what you'd find in a suburban strip mall.  Our party had Mu Shu, schezuan prawns, noodles, sesame chicken, and chicken with broccoli. All fine - but none standout.  Service was good. I'll keep searching for more tasty alternatives in Chinatown next time.
author: Stuart S.

description:
Decent priced and very good tasting, however I wish I hadn't seen the kitchen. Like others have said it is not much more than a hole-in-the-wall joint along the main drag. Although it is less touristic than the other restaurants it still feels "Americanized."
It appears to be a family run business so the service was lacking (speaking was no problem) and I could easilty see it taking a while to get served when it becomes busier. I would certainly recommend this for non-germphobics who are fine with average service.
author: X to the Z M.

description: Not fancy at all or big, but friendly and the food was good. I had egg foo young, which was really tasty.
author: Yelpy O.

description: The food was pretty good. The shrimp fried rice was my favorite.
author: Rosie S.

description:
I came here for lunch and ordered an orange peel chicken dish off the regular menu (it wasn't on the lunch menu) and thought it was alright. It seemed excessively bright coloured and I like for the peel to be visible in that dish. 

The staff was prompt and helpful. Complimentary tea. Rice costs extra unless you order off the lunch menu.
author: Cinth A.

description: Great place, just what the fam and myself were looking for during our trip to SF! The BBQ pork fried rice was delicious as was the Sweet and Sour Pork and Sesame Chicken. Hole in the wall atmosphere was great and so was the service. Definitely visiting the Snow Garden again!
author: J M.

description:
After my very first Chinese New Year Parade my boyfriend and a friend decided when in Rome...you get the picture! So we took a stroll around Chinatown in search of a good yet inexpensive dinner to ring in the New Year. We walked to Sam Wo - yeah not waiting for an hour in the cold - then there was the walk past The Four C's - full house signs in the window. So we kept wondering around and stumbled upon Snow Garden. 

Snow Garden is a hole in the wall along touristy Grant Ave. but their food is not half bad. Portions are very generous and the service was swift and quite good. We had the vegetarian special (soup, egg roll. fried rice and delicious vegies) as well as Broccoli with Oyster Sauce and Singapore Style rice noodles with veggies. All meals are cooked fresh - I know this because I could see the cooks in the kitchen chopping and cooking right from my table. 

I recommend this place to anyone who wants to save a buck, can deal with a hole in the wall restaurant and a small wait. Enjoy Chinatown the way I did tonight!!
author: Heidi S.

description: Bland and greasy.  We had two lunch specials (sweet and sour and beef chow fun) and neither were good. The beef chow fun did not have much flavor and the meat seemed soggy. The pineapples in the sweet and sour had a strange taste. Would not return.
author: Bryan L.

description:
This little place is an authentic gem in the midst of 'tourist-geared' Chinese Restaurants in Chinatown. Everyone knows that the 'real' Chinatown starts on Stockton and that Grant Ave Chinatown is just for 'dumb' tourists. Well, this place is no tourist destination. Family-owned, it's friendly, fast and very-very-VERY tasty. 

I have been here several times and never disappointed. Just yesterday, I felt like I was coming down with a cold. The first thing I did (my proven remedy) was to go to the Chinese place and gobble down a bowl of Hot & Sour Soup - the hotter the better. Never failed me. 

This is the best place equally for a quick bite or a big family dinner. The place is not fancy: no gilded lions or lavish art. However, this is the best place, visiting or not, for an authentic Chinese meal among all the expensive, but bland, restaurants on Grant Avenue.
author: Tatyana S.

description: I ordered the beef and broccoli dish here; maybe I had something else in mind but it didn't live up to my expectations of how it should have been. It was kind of bland and lacked the savory flavor I was hoping it would have. The service was pretty good though, and the sound of an old Chinese man playing an erhu outside added an interesting effect to my Chinatown experience.
author: Hena S.

description:
OMG this place is fabulous! I went there yesterday while walking through China Town, and I must say I was pleasantly surprised. Walking in I found that the decor left a little to be desired, but what they lack in ambiance they fully make up for in flavor! We are on a budget, so we only got fried rice and eggrolls, and they were the best eggrolls I have ever had! The fried rice was delicious too, with huge chunks of scrambled egg in there...LOVE it!
The service was great as well. The waiter was polite and gracious. He was the only waiter there, and I felt kind of bad for him as it was super busy, but he was on top of everything!
I will definitely be going back, wish I lived closer as I want it RIGHT NOW!
author: savannah f.

description: I saw the reviews on Yelp and decided to venture in. My food was quick in coming out and the waiter switched the beef in my dish to BBQ pork per my request.  It was okay food and portions were on the small side.  My pork chow fun was greasy and the pork tasted old.  Would not write home to Mom about this place!
author: Tonya V.

description: Good food, great prices. We ordered one neat and two bowls of steamed rice, more than enough for two.
author: Cindy A.

description: The server isn't the fastest in the world but he was a nice guy. Food was good although the chow mane chicken was a little dry. General chicken was good
author: Oscar M.

description: Food was pretty good, no complaints there. Portions were acceptable for the price. Service was always on it. Only concern is seeing waiter cut raw chicken in back and not sure how much washing was done before he came back out to wait on patrons.  But you never know what happens in back kitchens; just happen to have direct view of this one. Rating a 4 as we would eat it again.
author: Chad W.

description: Came here for lunch with a friend and had the braised tofu over rice dish.  The tofu was nice and tender, cooked perfectly.  The dish also had lots of bok choy and mushrooms and carrots.  The sauce was so so.  The size of the dish was very generous.  The place was pretty empty too so no waiting.
author: B. Y.

description: Went here with my family.  It is a small restaurant but the food is good.  the egg rolls are good.  the egg drop soup needed something.  it was bland.  the mushrooms, snow peas, water chestnuts and rice was really bland.  the chicken chow mein was good but could have used a bit more kick.
author: J S.

description: I ran across this restaraunt on accident while walking around the City by myself.  I absolutley loved it!  It was cheap, friendly service, and great food!  I decided to take my family there a month later.  They loved it also!  Very kid friendly and won't kill your wallet to feed the entire family.  I will definitely return. :-)
author: Marcy B.

description: So this place doesn't look like much but the food is acceptable. Some was better than others. The Hunan Beef was pretty good. I enjoyed that they used bamboo chutes rather than water chestnuts.  The Singapore street noodles was also good but nothing special. The twice cooked pork that my husband ordered was ok. We also had it stickers that were really just ok. Now the hot an sour soup, that was AMAZING!  If you don't  like spicy food this isn't for you but if you enjoy a nice spicy soup it is fantastic.
author: Alicia H.

description: Fantastic dumplings! This is the real deal people!
author: Gon Z.

description: I was actually walking down Grant to another restaurant when this little hole-in-the-wall caught my eye. Rather than even check Yelp, I decided to be bold and walk in.  I ordered orange peel chicken and shrimp chow mein to go.  The cost was $24 and the cashier said she prefers cash to credit so I handed her $40.  She placed $6 change on the table.  I just stared and she didn't seem to see the problem.  I asked what the price was again and she finally "realized her mistake" and put down the remaining $10.  I guess I'll give them the benefit of the doubt on this one that it was an accident.  Anyway, the food was strikingly fast and the food was pretty good.  The chow mein was generously sized (though more shrimp and veggies would have been welcome) and the orange peel chicken was enormous.   The chicken was OK but I don't think I'd order it again.  I liked the chow mein better, and next time I might ask to pay extra to add chicken or beef and more veggies.  Overall I would give the food and service four stars, minus one for short changing me.
author: Gordon L.

description: I visited Chinatown town on vatcation and found this place while walking around. 4 of us went there, the service was good. And very quick. :D the food was really good. We all shared the wonton soup, potstickers, chicken chow mein and a beef and rice dish. I would reccomend this place :D :D and the prices were fair.
author: Haley H.

description:
3.5 STARS.  Hole in the wall restaurant with surprisingly good food.  I'm not a local but I always start off my trip to SFO with lunch here.  

I've been here about 4 times over the course of 10 years...I thought their BBQ Pork was very well seasoned and delicious.  I've been very happy with the freshness and quality of the ingredients.

I'm not a big fan of beef at Chinese restaurants or Chicken, unless it is strictly white meat, but Snow Garden does a decent job at it.  I would rate this restaurant somewhere between "A-OK" and "I'M A FAN".
author: Rafa D.

description: Food was tasteless. Got cold really fast. Some feels like it was microwaved. Seafood was barely thawed, definitely not up to the quality you would expect for San Francisco  .
author: Eric S.

description: It was good. Especially egg plant with garlic source was great and BBQ Beef and kum pao shrimp was just ok.
author: Natsu Y.

description:
Whenever we go to Chinatown, we go here. The lunch specials are cheap and plentiful, the staff is very nice (ON one visit, I complimented the waiter on our Chow Fun noodles, and he went and brought the chef out so we could meet him. Very nice man).

I like it becasue it's a nice contrast to the more tourist-y places on Grant. It's nothing extraordinary, but I've been visiting this place since high school, so it's very comforting coming back.
author: Kathleen B.

description: The portions were small, the food was bland, the bathroom was almost as dirty as the one at the bart station.
author: amara k.

description:
Stopped in this place and the continuous noise of the chatter reminded me of why I love authentic restaurants.  I have not been to China, but during a hectic lunch rush it feels like I was there.

Great atmosphere.  fresh and HOT food. Not spectacular, but definitely worth stopping by.
author: Scott M.

description: Tried this place based on Yelp reviews - so much easier than just picking randomly, especially in Chinatown. Not much atmosphere, but we weren't really expecting that. Food was OK - certainly edible, but nothing special.  Prices were reasonable ($8-$10 for typical entrees) except for the eggrolls-3 for $6 -they were small and were mostly rolled wanton rappers.  We ordered 4 dishes: Lemon Chicken - it was OK, but not much lemon flavor.  Beef with Peppers - didn't taste like a Chinese dish or any version of this dish we've tried before.  The beef was soft and shredded (not slices of beef that would be expected) and was in a light brown gravy rather than a typical Chinese sauce.  It didn't taste bad, just different.  Orange Peel Beef - two out of three of us thought this was the best dish we had.  Shrimp Fried Rice - other Yelp reviews said this was great - it was good, but not great.  Had to pay an extra $1.50 for steamed rice - we ordered two and it came in small cups.  Considering how cheap steamed rice is, we thought that it was pretty skimpy.  Service was good (although they did bring the wrong order: Orange Peel Chicken instead of Orange Peel Beef, as ordered - the mistake was corrected immediately).  The hot tea was typically good, but we weren't offered a refill pot.  Soda is in cans.  They do have one restroom that is acceptable.  We were hungry so we ate everything, but we noticed people at other tables left good amounts of food on their plates.  Not a standout experience, but it was OK - no major complaints. As others have mentioned, if you want to pay by credit card, they tell you that they have to run the card next door.  If I hadn't read about this in other Yelp reviews, I would have been freaked out when they told me they were leaving with my card.  Weird, but at least they are trying to be accommodating since they obviously don't have the equipment to run the card in their restaurant.  Better than Cash Only, I guess, but still unsettling.
author: TL R.

description:
Visting SF from L.A. and staying near Chinatown, so decided to seek out a well rated Chinese place nearby for dinner. This one had the best reviews, so I tried it. I found it kind of blah. They were nice enough and service was relatively quick, which exception of getting the bill. I ordered the beef with tender chinese greens, which turned out to be beef with mixed vegetables, and rice. The rice tasted like it had been boiled in murky water. The beef was not too fatty, but did have that pounded into submission feature prevalent in many low caliber Chinese places. It didn't taste old, but it wasn't super fresh either. The vegetables were tender, and generally the dish was ok in terms of flavor. The whole bill including tip came out to $13 for one person. It was medium-low quality and just kind of run of the mill. I wouldn't avoid the place if it was the only option, but I won't intentionally go back either.

To be fair, I DO live in the town with the best Chinese restaurant ever - http://www.yelp.com/biz/great-wok-burbank - so these guys had difficult competition where I am concerned.
author: E S.

description: Beef chow fun was the most horrible I've ever tasted. Everytime I step on the floor in the restroom my shoes sticks onto the floor. Might as well go to Panda Express for some better tasting fake Chinese food.
author: Bryan Q.

description: My friend and I chose this place through Yelp! We wanted Chinese food and this place was close and received 4 stars. The outside and the inside look very hole-in-the-wall ish but it has been my experience that some holes-in-the-walls serve amazingly authentic food. The inside is small--about 10 or so tables. On the day, we went it was very understaffed--one waiter, one cleaning lady and one chef so service was sloooooooooww. We ordered two dishes to share-the spicy tofu (without pork) and sweet and sour prawns. We also got two bowls of rice. Once the food arrived...it was really delicious. The rice was soft and warm. The prawns had some crunch and the sweet and sour sauce hit the spot. The tofu wasn't very spicy though. So it just tasted like tofu with some sauce...I'm used to more chunky tofu and more pepper. The bill came out to $24 which is really a great price for a meal that left us quite full.
author: Esther E.

description: This place has the most excellent food I have tasted.  I actually have changed my favorite restaurant in Chinatown to this restaurant.  I will not name the old favorite.  Everything I ate was good, fresh, and hot!   I ordered the combination C for 2 that had the mongolian beef, shrimp fried rice, chicken salad, and lemon chicken.  EXCELLENT!!!!!  This place is the best!  Our server was very nice.  The food came out lickedy split.  If you don't eat here you are missing out on some wonderful food!  Thank you, I will be back monthly.
author: Allison C.

description: Standard non-dimsum, inexpensive Chinese food.  Snow Garden lacks healthier veggie-heavy options- most dishes favor meat plus sauce over rice or mixed with chow mein or chow fun.
author: devin j.

description: THE BEST FOOD IN CHINATOWN!!!! The food is great, you have to get  the BBQ fried rice and the potstickers, all of their soups are yummy too. They are huge 2-3people could easily share it! We have been there many, many times and would only go here if we eat in Chinatown. The same waiter is in there all the time and he serves you like you are in a 5 star place. He is as sweet as can be, they do take CC, and it's onw of the BEST kept secrets in SF for sure!! Def check it out,  Oh yeah, we get a ton of food for all under $20 for two and FREE hot tea all the time!
author: Heather L.

description:
I'll admit, I haven't done a lot of eating in China town, so I can't really speak to whether Snow Plum is the "best" -- as some other reviewers have called it -- but my lunch experience was wholly unremarkable.  

The service was great, the prices were fair, but the food was fairly bland.

Pretty sure my Chow Mein was warmed up in the microwave before serving.  It had that microwaved-one-minute-too-long thing going.
author: frank f.

description: I've been to San Francisco four times (2001, 2003, 2004 and 2006).  Every time I go to Chinatown, I eat lunch at the Snow Garden.  I really like the food, the ambiance... everything.  The food is great.. the service is super.  I'm looking forward to eating there again when i travel to SF this coming Dec. 26-29, 2008.  I always eat the sweet and sour pork.  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.   RC in Austin, Texas
author: Austin T.

description: food sucks, way overpirced. walk couple more blocks u can get better food for 1/3 the price. greedy owner dont go!
author: Ronald W.

description: I have to say we were hesitant about going here because it was a hole in the wall. One man was servicing all the tables so our wait was a bit on the long side but still was good service. Always scary to order food from something like this but we were pleasantly surprised that every dish we ordered was fantastic! The Peking Spare Ribs were delectable and so was the Orange Peel Beef. Definitely worth coming back. You'll taste the heart and soul in the cooking.
author: Romer G.

description: We were on a road trip as a family and stopped here for lunch while visiting SF's Chinatown in 2002.  We were hungry, and our boys at the time were 8 and 12 years old.  Every ten paces we had menus thrust at us from various restaurants.  Not liking that type of advertising and turning us off completely, we saw the Snow Garden which had a menu in the window.  When we walked inside and decided this was our lunch place, it was the best decision.  Not only did my husband and I love it, but our two sons did, too.  The food was incredibly fresh and was the quintessential Chinese food, in my opinion.  It was quiet inside and not too busy at the time.  Since we live in Washington state, we're unfortunately not able to eat here regularly.  Of course, when we go back to San Francisco, we'll definitely go back to the Snow Garden for both the food and the good memories of a great family vacation.  It's great to see that yelpers are raving about this place.
author: N W.
